body:
Demonstration:
1. Open nvi (BSD nvi).
2. Type `1000000afnord` then ESC.
3. Screen fills up almost instantly.
4. Open neovim.
5. Tyle `1000000afnord` then ESC.
6. Wait... and wait... and wait...

Originally pointed out by [this rant](http://www.galexander.org/vim_sucks.html) (not mine).

comment_data.body:
For what it's worth unicode handling seems to play a part in this.

``` sh
$ cat -v test_case 10000afnord^[:q!

$ time nvim -u NONE --headless --cmd 'set encoding=latin1' -s test_case
-- INSERT --:q!
real    0m4.290s
user    0m4.215s
sys     0m0.019s

$ time nvim -u NONE --headless -s test_case
-- INSERT --:q!
real    0m8.137s
user    0m7.494s
sys     0m0.022s

$ cat -v test_case2 20000afnord^[:q!

$ time nvim -u NONE --headless --cmd 'set encoding=latin1' -s test_case2
-- INSERT --:q!
real    0m16.957s
user    0m16.801s
sys     0m0.061s

$ time nvim -u NONE --headless -s test_case2
-- INSERT --:q!
real    0m38.323s
user    0m36.279s
sys     0m0.116s
```

Did some basic profiling (the test_case2 utf8 case):

```
480799   41.1119  nvim                     getvcol
275905   23.5919  nvim                     utfc_ptr2len
128529   10.9902  nvim                     win_lbr_chartabsize
115348    9.8631  nvim                     win_nolbr_chartabsize
85996     7.3533  nvim                     ptr2cells
70245     6.0065  nvim                     win_linetabsize
3115      0.2664  no-vmlinux               /no-vmlinux
```

and the latin case:

```
303413   41.2668  nvim                     getvcol
126554   17.2124  nvim                     win_nolbr_chartabsize
124547   16.9395  nvim                     ptr2cells
106184   14.4419  nvim                     win_lbr_chartabsize
64269     8.7411  nvim                     win_linetabsize
2426      0.3300  no-vmlinux               /no-vmlinux
```

Some basic call stack analysis most time is spent in `insert_enter-> insert_check -> validate_cursor`
But it's strange it is getvcol as the number of columns to check doesn't grow quadratically...

some quick flamegraph for the utf8 case
![append](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1363104/12730759/b306d27c-c92d-11e5-85bb-d69e5326dc7c.png)
but again, I would expected "cursor management" to be linear in the file size...

sorry confused lines and columns... Yes it is quite common vim needs to reprocess a line from start. But think the biggest contribution here is (times insert mode is entered)*(number of colums) I suspect if the same amount inserting was done without entering/exiting insert mode it would be much quicker, but still an asymptotic ncolumns^2 time cost.

emacs-devel recently had a [related discussion](https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/emacs-devel/2015-12/msg00385.html) regarding macro performance. (See also [emacs bug 13675](http://debbugs.gnu.org/cgi/bugreport.cgi?bug=13675).)

> The main problem, in a nutshell, is that to get to the next visual
> line, you need to traverse all the characters of the preceding line.
> Going backward (which happens every time you type C-p, and also many
> times behind the scenes, e.g., when Emacs needs to determine where to
> set the window start for next redisplay) is even more problematic,
> since Emacs can currently only do that by starting from the beginning
> of the previous _physical_ line (there's an optimization in this
> regard for preposterously long lines, but it loses accuracy -- it
> could cause horizontal scrolling when you move point vertically).
> 
> ...
> 
> Repeating a keyboard macro without intervening other actions means that
> the macro, after achieving its changes, has to progress to the next
> position where executing it makes sense as its last part.

Of course, Vim doesn't have variable-pitch fonts, and there's definitely low-hanging fruit that could be picked...

Inserting (without `'paste'`) a very long URL-encoded string triggers this issue. This happened when I used `<C-R>=$FOO` in insert-mode, where `$FOO` is an env var with the following contents.
